content.description:
This route begins with some interesting stemming and liebacking. After the second bolt, move up and right to the arete on big holds. The fourth bolt, which protects the crux, can be clipped from a nice stance. The crux itself is a neat boulder problem involving crimps, side pulling, and a tough move to a good right hand from which to clip the next bolt.

From here, things ease up, but not too much as you're left pumped and pulling up to a strenuous mantel before finishing on a slightly runout but easy slab.

It is also apparently possible to go out right at the crux on larger holds, bringing the grade down to 11b.
content.protection: 6 Bolts to anchors consisting of 2 Metolius rap hangers and 2 chains.
content.location:
Look for the cleanly cut column forming a roof at about 20' with a bolt at its lip. This line begins just left of here in a L-facing corner.

After the crux, ascend directly up the bolt line, ignoring the two bolts splitting leftward which mark the finish for Fotzhobel 12c.

content.description: This route starts out with somewhat insecure moves straight off the deck, with the added bonus of a bad landing if you blow it before making the first clip. The climbing remains technical and sustained until a restful stance below the obvious crux of the route, the overhanging wall split by a tips-width crack. Clip the bolt(probably very hard to reach for short people), and go for it! Anchors are a body length above the crux bolt.
content.protection: Bolts. A few small cams might be appreciated too. This route shares its anchor with Promiscuity Crack.
content.location: One of the furthest left routes at the Dark Side. Look for an overhanging wall split by a thin crack with a bolt.

content.description: One of the several bolted cracks at the Dark Side.  Excellent sustained finger and hand jams eventually take you to the interesting boulder-problem finish.
content.protection: This climb is well protected and takes gear to 2" plus a 2 bolt anchor.  Alternatively you can clip the 4 bolts that are all next to excellent gear placements.
content.location: Just left of the Wire Brush Haircut

content.description: Follows a crack in a shallow R-facing dihedral to a stance before a right leaning finger crack which leads up a left-facing ramp through the crux. Lock and lieback to a stemming stance and clip the chains on the left.
content.protection:
Gear up to 2 or 3" works well. Save a finger-sized piece for the finish.

Alternatively, there are 6 bolts, the last of which might be a tad awkward to clip.
content.location: Toward the left side of the Dark Side. Look for a clean, hexagonal break near the top which forms a nice-looking finger crack on its left side marking the finish for the route to the left ('The Virgin' 11b).

content.description: Decent route. After the third bolt on God route go left. There is a large pocket over the roof. Don't fall near the chains, you'll be a little ways past the last bolt.
content.location: Around the corner from Wire Brush Haircut, look for the big roof.

content.description: Another burly Dark Side sport route. The first few feet are pretty casual, but don't get too used to it. Once you pass that first bolt, you're working hard until you get your feet over the roof. There isn't much of a distinct crux on this route,  just pretty sustained 5.11 for the middle half of the route.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains. Wire brush optional.
content.location: Just right of the 30ft tall detached column that looks like it might fall down if you look at it wrong.

climbs.name: Good Friday
climbs.fa: Todd Montgomery, A. Casile, A. Frisbee- 1995

content.description: Stemmy moves down low lead to a step left, and then a nice finish on a fun finger crack.
content.protection: 4 bolts, plus an optional finger sized cam will get you to the two bolt anchor
content.location: The bolted line just left of the obvious Safety Dance crack.

content.description: This climb starts out as a scaly chosswidth, but it turns into quality climbing once you get through the first 15 feet or so. From the ground, climb the scaly but easy wide crack. The rock quality cleans up considerable once you reach the roof with a hand crack in it. You can clip a bolt on the 5.12 route TVOD at this point if you want. After pulling the first roof, work your way up the left arching 4" crack. Now you're under a roof split by two cracks ranging from about 1-3", with a surprising amount of exposure below you. Pull some very fun roof moves and you're pretty much done. The bolts out right didn't seem to work sell for setting up a TR so we built a gear belay above the lip and walked off the top once done(some additional shenanigans omitted). I know my description makes it sound utterly terrible, but it's worth checking out for the two roof cruxes and the 4" arching crack(if you're into that sort of thing).
content.protection: Recommended rack in new Camalot sizes: one #5, one or two #4s, two or three #3s, two #2s, two #1s, one #.75, and a handful of alpine draws. There are anchor bolts at the top of TVOD that you might be able to use, although that's not what we wound up doing.
content.location: On the far left side of the Dark Side wall. This climb is just left of TVOD and Chasing a Snake(names painted at the base of the wall)

content.description: This is a fun crack climb ranging in size from fingers to thin hands.  After the initial crack you get a pretty good rest stance right before the crux at the top.
content.protection: Gear up to 2" should have you set on this one.  This climb is well protected. Use the anchor for the route to the left, Safety Dance.
content.location: Immediately left of Wire Brush Haircut.
